item.title: Counseling Services Available
item.description:
Article Category: Student Services
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

FREE Counseling Services are available for enrolled KCC students this fall.  

Through Transformative Growth Counseling, services are available on campus on Tuesdays, 10am-5pm in Student Affairs, D228.

Students can get help if they are experiencing:

  • Anxiety
  • Depression
  • Relationship conflicts
  • Lack of motivation 
  • And more....

Support is also available related to:

  • Domestic abuse
  • Transportation issues
  • Stress management
  • Homelessness
  • Single Parents/Childcare
  • Bi-lingual/Spanish Translation Serices
  • Andmore....

Please refer them to Stephanie Ochoa, MSW (pictured)  

Call 630-731-2125 or email stephanie@transformativegrowth.org to schedule an appointment.

Information is also available from Meredith Purcell, director of student success, at 815-802-8514 or mpurcell@kcc.edu.

Counseling is confidential and the first 5 sessions are FREE. For long-term treatment, payments are accepted including insurance, self-pay, and sliding scale.

Author: Meredith Purcell
Article Date: 8/26/2019
Expires: 9/6/2019
item.author: Meredith Purcell

item.title: Thanks from TRIO Talent Search & Upward Bound
item.description:
Article Description: As we wrap up another successful summer enrichment program for our Talent Search and Upward Bound scholars, we want to thank the KCC campus community for accommodating and welcoming our students on campus. A special thanks to Athletics for use of the gym and equipment, along with Media for accommodating our print requests in a speedy manner, Custodial for assisting with set-ups and always having the college center ready for our morning sign-in and lunch times, and KCC Police for unlocking the 3D printing lab and the overall safety of our students. With the continued support of everyone on campus, we were able to enrich and shape the minds of our young pre-college scholars! This year we implemented a new 3D Printing class for our students and this would not have been possible without John Boudreau and Deb Daun for their guidance and support. A special thanks to Dr. Catalano, lab managers, and the administrative assistants in L355 for your assistance with reserving labs and lab supplies for our instructors and students. Kudos to Information Technology for ensuring software was downloaded and attending to our requests in a timely manner. TRIO Talent Search and Upward Bound Team
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:
As we wrap up another successful summer enrichment program for our Talent Search and Upward Bound scholars, we want to thank the KCC campus community for accommodating and welcoming our students on campus. A special thanks to Athletics for use of the gym and equipment, along with Media for accommodating our print requests in a speedy manner, Custodial for assisting with set-ups and always having the college center ready for our morning sign-in and lunch times, and KCC Police for unlocking the 3D printing lab and the overall safety of our students. With the continued support of everyone on campus, we were able to enrich and shape the minds of our young pre-college scholars!

This year we implemented a new 3D Printing class for our students and this would not have been possible without John Bordeau and Deb Daun for their guidance and support. A special thanks to Dr. Catalano, lab managers, and the administrative assistants in L355 for your assistance with reserving labs and lab supplies for our instructors and students. Kudos to Information Technology for ensuring software was downloaded and attending to our requests in a timely manner.

TRIO Talent Search and Upward Bound Team

item.title: Commencement Thank You!
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

KCC's 50th commencement ceremony was a special day for more than 200 students and their families.

Planning committee co-chairs, Kim Harpin and Meredith Purcell would like to express their appreciation to all those who contributed to the success of Saturday's program.  Task force members who meet monthly to plan the day; administrators who organize students, seat guests and lead groups into and out of the gym; and students who help with special tasks.  Katelynn Ohrt and her students for growing flowers that adorn the stage; accounting staff who help students purchase caps and gowns; PPD staff who work tirelessly to set up and take down equipment and chairs; and security staff who help maintain order.  A special thank you to Sharon Hoogstraat and Vanessa Lopez for handling so many details associated with every aspect of the event to ensure we all stay on track.

 


Author: Student Services
Article Date: 5/14/2019
Expires: 5/17/2019

item.title: College Drive Roadway Construction Project
item.description:
Article Description: College Drive Roadway Consturction Project
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​

College Drive Repair Project

Beginning Monday, May 13th, the college will start renovations to the College Dr. roadway at the west entrance into the campus. The work to repair and re-surface the road will go from River Road all the way to the bus stop by the main courtyard. The work is expected to take up to three weeks depending on weather conditions. At times, there will be partial lane closures, however, it is only anticipated to include two or three days where the entire road will be closed to all traffic. At times during the three week duration, there will also be minor curb and gutter repairs completed by the baseball and softball fields. During the three week schedule, roadway construction vehicles will be staged in the parking lot next to the wind tower.

The Ice Arena road will not be affected at any time. Vehicle traffic in and out of the campus is encouraged to use this entrance. All delivery, construction, and commercial vehicles should be directed to the east road entrance. When driving near the work area please follow all construction signage, use caution, and be aware of all construction vehicles and workers. Vehicle traffic to west campus should use the road off the circle drive by the Arts and Science building. Notices related to closings and changes in road use will be posted on the portal and sent out by email.

  • Please see the anticipated work schedule below. Any questions should be directed to Rich Soderquist at ext. 8173.Thank you for your patience and cooperation as we complete this important project.

 

PROJECT START DATE: Monday, May 13th

    • Week 1- Concrete Improvements per Plan (Estimated Duration, 5 Working Days & Weekend for Curing Period)
      • Includes ALL Concrete Demo and Replacement per Plan, Includes Excavation for Class D Patches and PCC Base Course, 6-Inch
  • Week of Monday, May 20th
    • Monday – Milling Operations (Surface / Edge Milling Only)
    • Tuesday – Full Depth Binder Placement
    • Wednesday – Road Fabric Installation  (FULL ROAD CLOSURE)
    • Thursday, Flex Day / Off Day if Flex Day not Needed for Unforeseen Conditions / Weather Delays
    • Friday, Close Entire Entrance Drive – Surface Course Placement, 2.0" (FULL ROAD CLOSURE)
  • Week of Monday, May 27th
    • Budget 2-3 Working Days for Misc. Items (Thermoplastic Markings, Landscape Restoration / Punch List Items if Applicable)
      • Items to be coordinate while onsite for major construction activities

 

 

 

Author: Chief Rich Soderquist - Deputy Chief Eric Springer
Article Date: 5/6/2019
Expires: 5/20/2019
item.author: Eric Springer

item.title: Caring with Candy Event
item.description:
Article Description: Caring with Candy Event to Celebrate Collaboration
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Happy February!

The Culture of Caring Committee would like to invite all employees to celebrate our core value of collaboration during the month of February.  We already have a portal post emphasizing the meaning of collaboration for this month, but we want to take our core value of collaboration to the next level! 

We are inviting each department to participate in our "Caring with Candy" event on Thursday, February 14th.  Each department is being asked to donate bags of candy to distribute to students and staff around their respective areas during the day.  If your department does not interact with students or staff frequently, but you still wish to donate, please give your bag of candy to another department to distribute.  In addition to showing we care with candy, any employee who wears a cavalier cares shirt (available for purchase in the bookstore) may wear jeans on Thursday, February 14th.  Employees may also wear jeans if they contribute one or more of the following items to the food pantry: fresh fruit, ramen noodle cups, canned fruits, cups of mac and cheese, chips, cereal bars, popcorn, jerky, or boxed meals.  A collection bin will be available at the front desk for contributions and you are always welcome to drop off contributions directly to the food pantry.  

We are excited to celebrate our core value of collaboration during the month of February!  If you have any questions, please contact Janet Fager at ext. 8124.  


Author: Culture of Caring Committee
Article Date: 2/7/2019
Expires: 2/15/2019
item.author: Beth Nunley

item.title: Collaboration
item.description:
Article Description: Collaboration
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

We are celebrating the core value of Collaboration during the month of February! Collaboration is creatively summed up by this short animated video; enjoy!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZnjJpa1LBOY&t=21s

Our KCC Cavaliers Care Book provides the following definition of Collaboration for KCC employees:

Collaboration is the process by which people work together to create or achieve a common goal.  At KCC, this is fundamental to our understanding of success.  We exemplify this commitment through the practice of open dialogue, consensus building, teamwork, and collective decision making at all levels of the institution.  We believe we are at our best when each member of the college community feels engaged in a common purpose, and when the unique talents of each individual are recognized as valuable and as contributing to our collective success.

We can demonstrate collaboration with the following actions and beliefs:

  • Understand that all divisions and departments share responsibility for student success.
  • Build positive, open, and honest relationships.
  • Work to break down the walls between faculty, administration, and staff.
  • Empower each other to get involved in the KCC community.
  • Participate in teams, work groups, and task forces with a spirit of partnership and cooperation.
  • Encourage fresh ideas and embrace diverse perspectives.
  • Have fun!!!


Author: Culture of Caring Committee
Article Date: 2/7/2019
Expires: 2/28/2019
item.author: Beth Nunley

item.title: Celebrating the KCC Cavaliers Care Book
item.description:
Article Description: Celebrating the KCC Cavaliers Care Book
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Several employees have asked what happens now after we completed the "How full is your Bucket" initiative and the launching of the Cavaliers Care Book.  To keep the momentum going, the Culture of Caring Committee would like to celebrate each core value of the KCC Cavaliers Care book over the upcoming months. 

Employees are encouraged to visit the portal to learn more about the monthly core value and to participate in planned activities to celebrate the core value.  Below is the tentative schedule for celebrating each of the KCC core values:

February 2019   –             Collaboration

March 2019        –             Learning

April 2019           –             Respect

May 2019            –             Excellence

June 2019            –             Integrity


Author: Culture of Caring Committee
Article Date: 2/1/2019
Expires: 2/22/2019
item.author: Beth Nunley

item.title: Holiday Fun Activities planned
item.description:
Article Description: Holiday Fun Week Dec 17-20 activities planned.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

The Culture of Care committee has designated the week of Dec 17-20 as Holiday Fun Week and has planned activities for each day.

 

Monday, Dec 17 is Candy Cane Monday – wear something red. Group photo at 11 a.m. Meet at the main reception desk.

Tournaments begin for Bags, Ping-Pong and Air Hockey.

Music Monday - Guess the holiday song at the main reception desk between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m.  Winner(s) announced at the holiday buffet on Thursday.

 

Tuesday, Dec 18 is Tinsel Tuesday – wear something sparkly and have your photo taken. Group photo at 11 a.m. Meet at the main reception desk. Dr. A, Dr. B, and Dr. G will travel through-out the main campus from 2-4 pm with cookies and milk, as well as carolers.

 

Wednesday, Dec. 19 is Holly Wednesday – wear something green and play Santa buckets in the Atrium from 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. Group photo at 11 a.m. Meet at the main reception desk.

 

Thursday, Dec. 20 is Ugly and/or Holiday sweater day. Group photo at 11 a.m. Meet at the main reception desk. Championship tournaments for Bags, Ping-Pong and Air Hockey and the annual holiday buffet.

Jeans may be worn on these days adhering to normal casual denim guidelines.

 

 

 


Author: Liz Becvar for David Cagle
Article Date: 12/4/2018
Expires: 12/20/2018
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: Cavaliers Care Book launch
item.description:
Article Description: Please stop by the Cavalier Room on Tuesday, Nov. 13 from 1-3 p.m. or on Wednesday, Nov. 14 from 9-11 a.m. to pick up your copy and to sign the KCC Pledge form, demonstrating your support and care.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Cavaliers Care Book

After months of collecting feedback, as well as further discussion and collaboration, we are ready to launch the distribution of the Cavaliers Care Book to all of our full and part time employees.

This booklet serves as a statement of our commitment to fostering a culture of care at KCC.  Our hope is that it will provide useful explanations, examples, and testimonials that better define and shape how we interact and serve one another.  It is a message written by KCC employees for KCC employees, detailing the actions that show that we, as a community, truly care!

Please stop by the Cavalier Room on Tuesday, Nov. 13 from 1-3 p.m. or on Wednesday, Nov. 14 from 9-11 a.m. to pick up your copy and to sign the KCC Pledge form, demonstrating your support and care. 

Refreshments will be available, and you will have the opportunity to Spin the Wheel of Care, in which everyone will receive a prize.

Author: David Cagle
Article Date: 11/12/2018
Expires: 11/14/2018
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: KCC Alumni Hosts Fundraiser for Foundation
item.description:
Article Description: KCC Alumni and Women's Giving Circle recipient Natasha Rademacher is hosting a Scentsy fundraiser to benefit the KCC Foundation.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

​In 2016 Natasha Rademacher was a student at KCC working toward a goal of becoming an Occupational Therapist.  She faced several barriers along the way due to reduced family income.  Her family of four spent months struggling to pay bills and learned to live with shut off utilities.  Providing food for her family had also become a challenge.  When Natasha confided in her KCC mentor, she was immediately referred to the Foundation.  Through assistance from the Women's Giving Circle, Natasha and her family were assisted with their utility bills and provided gift cards for food.  Through her hard work and with the assistance of the Foundation, Natasha graduated from Kankakee Community College in May of 2017.

Today, Natasha is doing well and has never forgot the impact the Foundation had on her life.   She has committed to give back by hosting a Scentsy fundraiser to benefit the Foundation. To order, you can go online at

Scentsy Foundation Fundraiser

and place an order.  All of her commision will be donated to the Foundation to benefit unmet and emerging needs throughout Kankakee Community College.

Author: Alumni Hosts Fundraiser to Benefit KCC Foundation
Article Date: 11/6/2018
Expires: 11/25/2018
item.author: Jennifer Zimmerman

item.title: Charity Basketball game
item.description:
Article Description: A charity basketball game Nov. 14 will emphasize working together for the greater good.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Content:

A charity basketball game Nov. 14 will emphasize working together for the greater good.

Tip off is 5 p.m. in the KCC Ryan Gymnasium. The community is invited.

One side of the court will be the KCC Veterans Association. The other side will be KCC police officers and KCC administrators.

Admission is $2 for students w/ ID and $5 for everyone else -- with children under age 12 free.

This year, pledge per basket donations are being accepted. Please contact Linh Williams at (815) 802-8628 or ltwilliams@kcc.edu for more information on how to donate. All donations are appreciated. All proceeds will benefit KCC Student Advisory Council and KCC's Veterans Association. Concessions for purchase will be provided by KCC's STEM Club.

Other perks of the event include a split-the-pot raffle and chances to laugh as you see the anguish on the court. 


Author: Linh Williams
Article Date: 11/1/2018

item.title: Windfall Provision Act Video Presentation
item.description:
Article Description: Here are retirement questions to consider: Do you expect to get Social Security in addition to your SURS pension when you retire?
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Windfall Provision Act Video Presentation

Here are retirement questions to consider:

  • Do you expect to get Social Security in addition to your SURS pension when you retire?
  • Did you know your Social Security benefits will be reduced because of your SURS pension?
  • Want to understand how Social Security and your SURS pension interact (the Windfall Provision)?

On Tuesday, Nov. 6, the KCC SUAA Chapter will show a video featuring John Meyers of the Springfield Social Security Office, who answered the above questions (and more) at a SUAA Foundation Meeting.

Come to the Workforce Development Center, Room D123, watch the 37-minute video and get the answers. It will be shown twice Nov. 6 – 11:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m.

"Mr. Meyers gave the best and clearest explanation of the windfall provision that I have heard," said  Mary Posing.

All KCC employees are invited. You are welcome to bring lunch to eat while you watch. 



Author: Mary Posing, KCC SUAA director
Article Date: 10/16/2018
Expires: 11/6/2018
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:


Kankakee Community College's Manufacturing Technology program is hosting a food drive during October to benefit the college's Food Pantry.

Non-perishable and canned items will be accepted. Especially welcome are "grab-and-go" options for a quick meal or snack, such as ramen noodle cups, macaroni and cheese cups, popcorn, cereal, granola bars or fruit cups. See complete list.

Donation bins are located on KCC's Riverfront Campus, outside Rooms L340 and W102; and at the entrance of the Manufacturing and Industrial Technology Center (MITC).

October is Manufacturing Month, and National MFG DAY is Friday, Oct. 5. These observances are designed to give manufacturers an opportunity to open their doors and show, in a coordinated effort, what manufacturing is, and isn't.

KCC's Manufacturing Technology program offers certificates and associate in applied science degrees, with specializations in Machine Tool; Welding; Industrial Maintenance; and Transportation, Warehousing, Distribution and Logistics (TWDL).

More information about the program is online, or phone Mark Anderson, program coordinator, at 815-802-8873.


Author: Mark Anderson

item.title: SUAA lunch and learn
item.description:
Article Description: There will be two sessions of a Lunch and Learn on Thursday, Sept. 27 with State University Annuitants Association Legislative Co-Chair Leo Welch.
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

There will be two sessions of a Lunch and Learn on Thursday, Sept. 27 with the State University Annuitants Association Legislative Co-Chair for Community Colleges, Leo Welch.

Welch will speak about recent legislation that, if passed, would affect you as a KCC employee. 

Please join him in the KCC Cavalier Room on Thursday, Sept. 27, 2018 either  from 11-11:40 a.m or noon - 12:40 p.m.

Time will be allowed for your questions.

Bring your lunch to eat during the presentation and the faculty association will provide cake for dessert! 

All KCC employees are invited. If you are not a SUAA member, now is an ideal time to join KCC's chapter and get a raffle ticket for the drawing to be held toward the end of March. Six prizes will be awarded. Maximum of one prize per person.

RAFFLE PRIZES!

  • Dinner for two ($50 gift card) at Brickstone Restaurant (2)
  • $30 Cinemark Movie Card (2)
  • $20 Amazon Gift Card (2)

The prize drawing will be at the final SUAA event for 2018-19 in March 2019! 

Ask your colleagues about SUAA. SUAA members: Bring new members to the Cavalier Room to join SUAA on Sept. 27 and both you and the new member will be entered in the raffle. 

Prospective members: See any of the following people at any time until the raffle in March to join SUAA and get a raffle ticket: Steve DePasquale, Bridget Bertrand-Essington, David Hermann, John Shivers, or Cindy Walters.

Author: Linda Guinn, KCC SUAA chapter president

Departments, or blended departments, will field teams of seven (7) players (larger teams allowed; however, only (7) players will be allowed to play at anytime, subs permitted).

item.title: Annual evaluation due dates are: 6/4 for non-supervisory staff and 6/18 for supervisory staff
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

It is that time again -- time for annual performance appraisals of administrators, professional/technical and supportive staff.

Completed appraisals are to be submitted to the Human Resources Office by June 4th for non-supervisory staff (full and part-time) and June 18th for supervisory personnel.

Evaluation process:

The process includes reflection on your accomplishments, how you met/exceeded last year's goals, and what specific goals/objectives await you in the coming fiscal year.

You should consult your immediate supervisor for his/her deadline which allows time for all levels of supervision to review evaluations before the appropriate Human Resources deadline.  Electronic evaluation forms are located on the HR Portal page under Documents in the Evaluations folder.

As part of this process, if the position description is not accurate, your supervisor should make proposed revisions and submit them to Human Resources with the evaluation.  A copy of your current description may be obtained by contacting Janet in HR at ext. 8124.  A "Specific responsibilities" section should also be included.

The process will be as follows:

1.  Complete a self-evaluation.

2.  Submit it as a Word document to your immediate supervisor. Schedule a meeting with him/her to discuss performance, review the completed tasks, establish new goals through May 2019 and complete the final evaluation. Note: Input/support from department directors should be solicited prior to this meeting.

3.  Sign the completed evaluation, get your immediate supervisor's signature, plus the appropriate department director's.  Keep a copy (or save it electronically). Your supervisor should do the same (for use during next year's evaluation process).

4.  Deliver a paper copy to Human Resources by the appropriate due date.

Please contact David Cagle at dcagle@kcc.edu or 815-802-8128 if you have any questions regarding this process.

Author: HR
Article Date: 5/30/2018
Expires: 6/18/2018

item.title: National Day of Silence
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​Today is the National Day of Silence, a nation-wide, student led movement to stand in unity with LGBTQ+ students and allies that are bullied and harassed.  The symbolism of students staying silent all day underscores the impact of intimidation and name calling on self-expression.  Yesterday members of KCC's Gay-Straight Alliance met with other local groups to discuss today and to begin to build a local safe space community for our common LGBTQ+ students. The evening included students from GSA groups from Kankakee High School, Momence High School, Bradly Bourbonnais High School and the student group PRISM from ONU, as well as participation from parents, faculty advisers and members of the local community.

item.title: Superheroes Day is Friday, April 27
item.description:
Article Description: Who doesn't love superheroes, am I right?
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

Who doesn't love superheroes, am I right?  Superheroes are awesome! Heroes are made by the path they chose, not the powers they are graced with.  So in observance of National Superhero Day, KCC would like to encourage all employees to dress-up as their own personal superhero on Friday, April 27th. 

Who is your personal superhero?  Batman, Iron Man, or Harley Quinn?  Or your local firefighter, police officer or military personnel? 

Employees will have an opportunity to earn the "Most Creative Award" and the "Employee Choice Award".  We are excited to celebrate National Superhero Day and would like to invite all employees for a group photo outside near the Meridian sculpture at 11 a.m. 4/27/18.

Author: Beth Nunley
Article Date: 4/23/2018
Expires: 4/27/2018
item.author: Elizabeth Becvar

item.title: KCC Law Week Activities
item.description:
Article Description: Consider attending one of the exciting free activities being held during Law Week!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​

On Monday, April 30 at 6:30 p.m., KCC's Paralegal/Legal Assistant Studies Program will host a panel discussion in the Iroquois Room with representatives from each branch of government. Participants scheduled are Jim Rowe, Kankakee County State's Attorney; Stephen Liehr, vice-chairman of the Kankakee County Board; Chief Judge Michael Kramer, 21st Judicial Circuit; and Jake Lee, Kankakee County Auditor. Dr. Kristine Condon, KCC professor and program coordinator, will moderate.

On Tuesday, May 1 at 6:30 p.m., a conversation with book author J. Dennis Marek will take place in KCC's Auditorium. Marek will talk with Walter Pieszka, the subject of his new book, "The Ultimate Survivor." 

On Wednesday, May 2 at 6:30 p.m., a Trivia Night benefiting Prairie State Legal Services will be in the KCC Iroquois Room. Members of the community are invited to form a trivia team and compete! Cost is $10 per person, or $50 for a team of six. All proceeds go to Prairie State Legal Services, a provider of free or low-cost civil legal aid services to the poor and the elderly in Kankakee and Iroquois counties.

On Thursday, May 3 at 6:30 p.m., a Passport to Civics fair will be held. This family-friendly event features voter registration, plus information about election judges, Kankakee County Teen Court, and KCC's Paralegal/Legal Assistant Studies and Law Enforcement programs. The poster contest winners will be announced and prizes awarded.

On Friday, May 4, from 10 a.m. - noon in Courtroom 300 at the Kankakee County Courthouse, there will be Illinois Appellate Court, Third District, oral arguments on two pending appeals. Seating is limited, and appropriate business attire is required. The Appellate Court visit is sponsored by the Kankakee County Bar Association and the Kankakee chapter of the Society of Women in Law. Justices will not comment on matters pending before the court or provide legal advice to courtroom spectators.

Author: Karen Richards
Article Date: 4/17/2018
Expires: 5/3/2018

item.title: Cap Challenge Wrapping Up
item.description:
Article Description: Would you like to have your name on a bench?
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:


Cap collection will end on Monday, April 30th.  Please have all caps turned in by the end of business on that day.  Once the students have everything sorted and weighed, we will know how many pounds we have and how many benches we will be able to purchase.  Currently it looks like we will have caps for four or more benches.  

If you, your department, or anyone you know in the community would like to sponsor a bench (roughly $250 each) please contact Alison Nakaerts or Linh Williams.  If your department would like to pool money, or host a doughnut fundraiser to raise the money, we can help you with logistics!  Keep in mind that if you are sponsoring a bench, your name(s) will be put on a plaque on the bench!!!

KCC would like to see the Cap Challenge continue past this year.  If anyone (or department) would like to take over leadership of the program next year, please contact Linh Williams.

Thank you,

Caps Committee
Linh Williams, Brian Yeoman, Sheila Pfaff & Alison Nakaerts

Article Content:

​Cap Challenge collection will stop at the end of April.  If you are collecting and are not on a team, we can get you a list of current teams.  

PPD recently picked up four benches similar to those in the above photo.  Our hope is to have enough caps with the final collection to get four more!

Faculty, feel free to offer competitions in your classes as some of you did last year!  Let's make this a bumper crop of caps!

Questions please see Linh Williams, Sheila Pfaff or Alison Nakaerts.

item.title: Blood Drive Next Week! We are still looking for signups!
item.description:
Article Description: BE SOMEONES RESCUE STORY
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

​

BE SOMEONES RESCUE STORY

Blood donors save lives! Be a lifesaver and sign up for our blood drive! 

Kankakee Community College Blood Drive

(located at 100 College Drive
Kankakee, IL 60901)

03/28/2018

09:00 AM - 01:00 PM

Please click https://ht.heartlandbc.org/donor/schedules/drive_schedule/2033995 to schedule your preferred donation time!

Our collection goal is 23

 

DID YOU KNOW?

  • Blood donation is a simple four-step process: registration, medical history and mini-physical, donation and refreshments.
  • The actual blood donation typically takes less than 10-12 minutes.  The entire process, from the time you arrive to the time you leave, takes about an hour.
  • Although an estimated 38% of the U.S. population is eligible to donate, less than 10% actually do each year.  This is why shortages occur.
  • Red blood cells (the most commonly transfused component) last only 42 days.
  • The average red blood cell transfusion is approximately 3 pints.
Author: Linh Williams
Article Date: 3/21/2018

item.title: SUAA Week Activities: March 26-29
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

​During SUAA Week KCC SUAA Chapter Board Members will be in the College Center (Mon. & Wed.) or Room D151 (Tues. & Thurs.) from 11-1 to answer questions about how the State Universities Annuitants Association advocates in Springfield for community college employees and how to empower yourself by becoming a member of SUAA.

 

On Tuesday, March 27, come to Room D151 to hear SUAA Executive Director Linda Brookhart speak about SUAA's advocacy for community college employees and SUAA's proposed solution to the state pension debt. Choose any of the following time slots: 11-11:30, 11:30-12, 12-12:30, 12:30-1.  Bring your lunch to eat during the presentation. All SUAA members and all KCC employees are invited!

 

New SUAA members will be entered in a raffle to win a $25 Amazon gift card. One $25 Amazon gift card will be given to a new member every day, Monday –Wednesday, during SUAA Week with 2 cards awarded on Thursday! A total of five $25 gift cards will be awarded. The sooner people join SUAA, the more chances they have to win!

 

Finally, All SUAA members and new members are invited to enjoy cake in Room D151 on Thursday, March 29, from 11-1 to celebrate SUAA and welcome our new members!

 

Watch your mailbox and email for more information. Go to http://kccsuaa.wixsite.com/kcc-suaa-website for more information about KCC SUAA.

item.description:
Article Description: Pack the Park Thursday, March 22 and show your support for the Cavaliers softball and baseball teams!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Content:

Pack the Park Thursday, March 22 and show your support for the Cavaliers softball and baseball teams!

Admission to both games will be free, and there will be free refreshments while supplies last.

The featured games will be played on KCC's home fields. The baseball team will play Prairie State College at 2:30 p.m. The softball team will play South Suburban College beginning at 3 p.m.

"Wear your "Scarlet Fever" T-shirt, to show your school pride. Don't have a shirt? The main information desk on the first floor will sell them during the week before the event for $5. T-shirts also will be sold at the game. For information phone Linh Williams, student life coordinator, at 815-802-8628.

Optional casual day
To participate in the casual day March 22, employees should wear a Scarlet Fever T-shirt, or a collared shirt with "Kankakee Community College" on it, or a business casual shirt and a KCC name badge or staff ID.

Other casual day guidelines:

  • Participation is optional.
  • Staff are asked to use their good judgment in choosing appropriate jeans. Inappropriate jeans include those with patches, fraying, excessive length, low-rise cut and/or very faded.
  •  Those who choose not to wear jeans should wear their normal work attire; or they can choose to wear a Red Fever T-shirt or KCC collared shirt along with their normal attire. 
  • All employee groups can participate. 
  • Please use good judgment in choosing whether to wear jeans. Depending on what is scheduled for a particular day, jeans may or may not be appropriate. Professional appearance is important, and all employees share the responsibility of representing the college.

    .

item.title: Sharing Life Events
item.description:
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Sharing Major Life Events

 

While everyone knows that the Portal  is a communication tool for work-related information, it may come as news that it can also be used to share major life events.

 

Here's a summary of different topics you can add to the Portal, and parameters which might come into play. As you will see, there are some cases where additional steps are needed to comply with FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974) and/or KCC policy.

 

There are a number of people across the college who can add articles to the Portal. They are welcome to add marriages, births and thank you's. Notices of deaths and employment changes include potential liability issues and therefore are more appropriate for marketing or human resources personnel to post.  

 

Births – Employee has a newborn child or grandchild. It's good to include as many of these details as possible: the baby's name, birthdate, weight and length at birth, his/her parents' names, names of the baby's brothers or sisters, baby picture, relationship to the employee, employee's title/work area at KCC. The employee needs to give consent for the information to be published.

Marriage – Employee gets married. It's good to include as many of these details as possible: wedding date, place, bride/groom names, employee's title/work area at KCC. The employee needs to give consent for the information to be published.

Death/condolences/serious illness – Death/serious illness of current employee's spouse, sibling, child or parent; death/serious illness of a current or retired employee. The affected employee must give permission to share information. In the case of an employee or retiree's death, an immediate relative or close trustee can give permission to share information. The initial permission can come verbally to another employee, but it must be shared in writing within a few days by the person who receives permission. The preferred method of written permission is the Illness & Condolences Form. It includes space for summaries of the information and confirms permission to share it.

Human resources or marketing will publish all death/condolence/serious illness articles. The details which are helpful are found on the Illness & Condolences Form located on the Human Resources Portal page under "documents". 

If the information about someone's passing is available before the services occur, the marketing department can send an email to all employees with the details, including date and times of services.

Thanks following death or illness of a loved one – Submit your note to Ellen Schmidt in the marketing office to have it included on the Portal.

Employment change – New full-time KCC employee; full-time KCC employee leaving or retiring; KCC employee changing to a full-time job within the college. Human resources will publish all employment change articles. Before publication, the change must first be approved by the board of trustees. Changes in employment and new employee names, titles, and departments will be included on the Portal shortly following either the board meeting where their employment is approved, or close to their first day on the job, whichever is later. Retiring and departing employees will be announced on the Portal prior to their last day, or after their last day, depending on the departing employee's preference.

Other life events – Consult the marketing office or human resources.

 

Anyone with questions is welcome to contact David Cagle at 8128 or Ellen Schmidt at 8279.

item.description:

Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)

Article Content:
Las Vegas FUN event for the win!!!!!  

Wow what a fun time! Thanks so much to everyone who came out to play a few games, eat some popcorn and enjoy the comradery of their fellow employees.  

The big prize winner of the basket of lottery scratch off tickets was Michael O’Conner. John Shivers won the Guess the Dice game with an answer of 422. The total number was 427. Also congrats goes out to Jamal Hawkins for having the best hand at the Poker Darts game.  

A huge shout of thanks to everyone who helped in any way either by helping to run games, hand out raffle tickets, pop popcorn, donate prizes or assisted with game accessories.

Special thanks to PPD for assistance in set up and clean up. We couldn’t have done it without our fantastic team of Tasha Klipp, Erica Billington, Tyler Wheeler, Deb Denson and Linh Williams.

Who knows…maybe we will have to make this an annual event!

item.description:

​

On Thursday, March 8th join your coworkers for a day of fun!  The FUN Task Force has planned 2 activities for the day.

"Color Your World" will be a dress up themed event.  Committee members will come around to each department/area the week of February 26th to let you draw a color from the basket.  Then on the 8th everyone in your area will dress in this color.  Be creative include accessories. You can even decorate your area if you want!  Let's see how colorful we can make KCC!   A group photo will be held at 11:45 am on the steps of the lower level of the library.

The second event will be a Vegas Game Day Open House to be held in the Cavalier room from 1:30 pm to 3:00 pm.  Come try your luck at a variety of games such as Blackjack, Poker darts, Bingo, Uno and more.  Prizes will be awarded to the luckiest.  Come stay as long as you can just be sure to give everyone in your area a chance to enjoy the fun.  Be sure to register for the grand prize to be awarded at the end of the day!

item.title: WYSE Thank You
item.description:
Article Description: Many thanks!
Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:
KCC hosted the regional 2018 WYSE – Worldwide Youth in Science and Engineering – Academic Challenge on February 6.  We had 190 students from 12 local high schools competing in seven different subject areas. The top teams and top individuals in each subject advance to the sectional WYSE competition at North Central College in March.  
I would like to express my gratitude to all the people and departments from around campus that helped make the competition a success. Alison Nakaerts has spent months planning and organizing the event; many thanks for all your hard work! Thank you, too to Mike Caparula, Allison Flory, Dr. Jessica Greminger, Aindrea Hogan, Michael Miller, Kelly Myers, Sheila Pfaff, Terese Roberson, Donna Schmidt, and Tyler Willis.  
Thank you to Aindrea Hogan, Monica Johnson, Dwayne Musick, and Adam White for helping out with a last minute request to give campus tours to the students!
Finally, gratitude to those people and departments that contributed from behind the scenes: the Athletic Department, Arena Food Services, ITS, Media, Marketing, the Foundation and the Physical Plant Department.
It would not have been possible for KCC to host this event without the willingness of all these people to share their time and effort—thank you for once again helping to make WYSE a huge success!    --Francesca Catalano

Article Category: Update (Faculty and Staff Newsletter)
Article Thumbnail:
Article Image:
Article Content:

Written Communication is next up in the general education outcome assessment rotation! Faculty members teaching courses with this outcome will be notified at the beginning of the spring semester. Later in the term those faculty members will receive a randomized list of a sample of their students; then all they will have to do is submit artifacts demonstrating those students' written communication abilities. Identifying information will be removed from the artifacts, and a small team of faculty will assess those items as part of a short-term summer research project.

Details regarding how to submit artifacts as well as for those interested in participating on the summer team will be provided after the break. For now, if you'd like to learn more about learning artifacts, a variety examples are being posted on the Teaching and Learning Center blog.

item.title: Power down to save money: 6/22
item.description:
Article Description: Adapted from an email from Rich Soderquist ... On Thursday, June 22, the college, in conjunction with our electric suppliers PJM and Commonwealth Edison, will be conducting a load reduction test. Last year, participation in this program by KCC resulted in a rebate to the college of over $13,000.00. By participating again we will be eligible for approximately $24,000 in rebates. So your support and participation is very much appreciated! The test is from 1-2 pm. However our Physical Plant staff will begin reducing power to building environmental and lighting systems at 12:45 pm. Classes do not need to be interrupted or cancelled, critical programs can be run, and any operations necessary to conduct business or for safety should continue. However I encourage any reduction or adjustments to non-essential electrical use by powering down during this time period. The college will be providing ice cream out on the north patio and all staff are encouraged to go out and enjoy some summer refreshment. Thanks again for your understanding and support during this program.

item.title: Portal implemention timeline
item.description:
Article Description: The portal implementaion is underway, and on schedule to be live by the end of June. See the timeline being used for the project by clicking here
Article Category: Update
Article Content:

Portal implemention timeline

​The portal implementaion is underway, and on schedule to be live by the end of June.

Here's the timeline being used for the project:

  • August 2016 – Information sessions w/students/faculty/staff
  • September 2016 – Finalization of project scope
  • September 2016* – “Scoping” call with Ellucian
  • October 2016 – Board of Trustees Meeting
  • January 2017* – Development/design work begin
  • March 2017 – Standup test portal site
  • April 2017 – Production portal site built
  • May 2017 – Begin populating portal site/Training of content editors
  • June 29, 2017 – KCC’s Portal goes LIVE

Note: although the project is on schedule, some dates are dependent on Ellucian, the software development company. Ellucian also is the software company for Colleague, the KCC Student Information System.

One thing to gleen from the timeline is that portal training is near. Editors of KCC's website received a message on April 21 inviting them to learn to edit portal content.

The training will be a two-hour session, with six times to choose from, on May 10 and 11. If you are a content editor and did not receive an invitation to training, contact Mike O'Connor.

Once the portal is populated and live, it will continue to evolve. Information will continue to migrate to it. Elements on the portal page might move or change to serve constituents better. In other words, users will probably see new/different things every now and then.

Anyone with questions about the portal project is invited to contact Michael O’Connor or Kari Nugent, who are leading the implementation team.​
